details.name: DNA methylation
details.description: A type of epigenetic modification that involves the addition of a methyl group to DNA, often occurring at cytosine-phosphate-guanine (CpG) sites.
details.findings: Metastatic colorectal cancer (CRC) patients have a unique DNA methylation profile in their circulating tumor cells (CTCs) compared to primary CRC patients and healthy donors, with specific CpG sites showing differential methylation patterns.

details.name: Haptoglobin
details.description: A protein that binds to free hemoglobin in the bloodstream.
details.findings: Haptoglobin levels were found to be elevated in COVID-19 patients compared to healthy controls.

details.name: C-reactive protein (CRP)
details.description: A protein produced by the liver in response to inflammation.
details.findings: CRP levels were significantly higher in severe COVID-19 cases compared to mild cases.

details.name: Interleukin-6 (IL-6)
details.description: A cytokine involved in inflammation and the maturation of B cells.
details.findings: IL-6 levels were correlated with disease severity in COVID-19 patients.

details.name: Ferritin
details.description: A protein that stores iron and releases it in a controlled fashion.
details.findings: Elevated ferritin levels were observed in COVID-19 patients with poor outcomes.

details.name: D-dimer
details.description: A fibrin degradation product, a small protein fragment present in the blood after a blood clot is degraded by fibrinolysis.
details.findings: High D-dimer levels were associated with increased mortality in COVID-19 patients.

details.name: miR-126
details.description: A small non-coding RNA molecule that regulates gene expression.
details.findings: miR-126 has shown robust predictive results for early CRC stages diagnosis and prognosis.

knowledge.subject: miR-126
knowledge.object: robust predictive results for early CRC stages

details.name: miR-1290
details.description: A small non-coding RNA molecule that regulates gene expression.
details.findings: miR-1290 has shown robust predictive results for early CRC stages diagnosis and prognosis.

knowledge.subject: miR-1290
knowledge.object: robust predictive results for early CRC stages

details.name: miR-23a
details.description: A small non-coding RNA molecule that regulates gene expression.
details.findings: miR-23a has shown robust predictive results for early CRC stages diagnosis and prognosis.

knowledge.subject: miR-23a
knowledge.object: robust predictive results for early CRC stages

details.name: miR-940
details.description: A small non-coding RNA molecule that regulates gene expression.
details.findings: miR-940 has shown robust predictive results for early CRC stages diagnosis and prognosis.

knowledge.subject: miR-940
knowledge.object: robust predictive results for early CRC stages

details.name: CExs-miRNA
details.description: Circulating exosomal microRNA, a type of small non-coding RNA molecule found in exosomes.
details.findings: CExs-miRNA has been reported as a potential biomarker with robust predictive results for CRC diagnosis and prognosis.

knowledge.subject: CExs-miRNA
knowledge.object: robust predictive results for CRC diagnosis and prognosis

details.name: MSI-H
details.description: A genetic marker indicating a high level of microsatellite instability.
details.findings: MSI-H status confers substantial improvements in clinical outcomes and decreased toxicities through Immune Checkpoint Inhibitors (ICI).

details.name: RAS
details.description: A family of genes that include KRAS, NRAS, and HRAS, often mutated in various cancers.
details.findings: RAS mutations necessitate a molecular-targeted approach in CRC treatment.

details.name: BRAF V600E
details.description: A specific mutation in the BRAF gene that is associated with poor prognosis in CRC.
details.findings: BRAF V600E had a negative prognostic value but is now predictive of response to combined targeted BRAF/EGFR inhibition, doubling survival over standard treatments.

knowledge.subject: BRAF V600E
knowledge.object: response to combined targeted BRAF/EGFR inhibition

details.name: MSI
details.description: A genetic marker indicating the level of microsatellite instability.
details.findings: The MSI status confers substantial improvements in clinical outcomes and decreased toxicities through ICI, offering patients long-term survival or near curative results.

details.name: Dihydropyrimidine Dehydrogenase (DPYD)
details.description: An enzyme involved in the metabolism of fluoropyrimidines, which are commonly used chemotherapeutic agents.
details.findings: DPYD variants can cause severe toxicity and even death in patients treated with fluoropyrimidines.

details.name: BRAF
details.description: A gene that, when mutated (especially V600E), is associated with poor prognosis in CRC.
details.findings: BRAF V600E had a negative prognostic value but is now predictive of the response to combined targeted BRAF/EGFR inhibition, doubling survival over standard treatments.

knowledge.subject: BRAF
knowledge.object: response to combined targeted BRAF/EGFR inhibition

details.name: Caspase-3
details.description: A key effector caspase in the apoptosis pathway.
details.findings: The article mentions the use of Caspase-3 as a biomarker but does not provide specific findings.

details.name: Ki67
details.description: A marker of cell proliferation.
details.findings: The article mentions the use of Ki67 as a biomarker but does not provide specific findings.

details.name: Ribonucleotide Reductase M2
details.description: An enzyme involved in DNA synthesis and repair.
details.findings: The article mentions the use of Ribonucleotide Reductase M2 as a biomarker but does not provide specific findings.

details.name: guanylate cyclase-C
details.description: A protein biomarker used in immunohistochemistry.
details.findings: Guanylate cyclase-C immunohistochemistry data was performed and interpreted by Guangjian Ma of Innovative Cellular Therapeutics Co.

details.name: hCRISPRs
details.description: Human CRISPR sequences involved in transcription and diagnostics.
details.findings: The article discusses the detection and validation of hCRISPRs in transcription and diagnostics, involving computational analyses and technologies like SHERLOCK and DETECTR.

details.name: Acetone
details.description: A ketone that can be detected in exhaled breath.
details.findings: Acetone levels change during activities such as exercising or fasting, making it an unreliable cancer biomarker despite its fruity odor.

knowledge.subject: Acetone
knowledge.object: during activities such as exercising or fasting

details.name: 2-Propanol
details.description: An alcohol that can be detected in exhaled breath.
details.findings: 2-Propanol is mentioned as a VOC but its origin and specific role as a biomarker are unclear.

details.name: Hexanal
details.description: An aldehyde that can be detected in exhaled breath.
details.findings: Hexanal is mentioned as a VOC but its origin and specific role as a biomarker are unclear.

details.name: Acetaldehyde
details.description: An aldehyde that can be detected in exhaled breath.
details.findings: Acetaldehyde is mentioned as a VOC but its origin and specific role as a biomarker are unclear.

details.name: 4-Heptanone
details.description: A ketone that can be detected in exhaled breath.
details.findings: The origin of 4-Heptanone is unclear, making it not recommended for use as a biomarker.

details.name: Hexanoic acid
details.description: A carboxylic acid that can be detected in exhaled breath.
details.findings: Hexanoic acid is mentioned as a VOC but its origin and specific role as a biomarker are unclear.

details.name: VOCs
details.description: A group of carbon-based chemicals that easily evaporate at room temperature.
details.findings: VOCs can be used as biomarkers for GI cancer, but their origins are often unclear and further research is needed.
details.notes: Exogenous factors like physical activities and smoking can change the pattern of VOCs.

knowledge.subject: VOCs
knowledge.object: exogenous factors like physical activities and smoking

details.name: Microbiome Data
details.description: Microbial community data used to differentiate between healthy and diseased states.
details.findings: Microbiome data analysis using XAI identified significant bacterial taxa associated with CRC.

knowledge.subject: Microbiome Data
knowledge.object: significant bacterial taxa associated with CRC

details.name: Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs)
details.description: Biochemical compounds released in human breath due to various metabolic processes.
details.findings: The study identified different VOCs in the breath of CRC patients compared to previous studies, which may be attributed to differences in mass-spectrometry devices, sample collection processes, and geographical variations.
details.notes: Further chemical analysis is needed to correlate biochemical pathways with the results.

knowledge.subject: VOCs
knowledge.object: CRC patients compared to previous studies

details.name: Alkenes
details.description: A type of hydrocarbon that is released due to oxidative stress.
details.findings: The main mechanism affecting the emission of alkenes is oxidative stress, which involves the balance between formation and scavenging of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and free radicals in the body.

knowledge.subject: Alkenes
knowledge.object: reactive oxygen species and free radicals

details.name: Alcohols
details.description: Compounds that originate from food, alcohol beverages, and the metabolism of hydrocarbons by cytochrome p450 enzymes.
details.findings: Alcohols in breath are derived from food, alcoholic beverages, and the metabolism of hydrocarbons by cytochrome p450 enzymes.

knowledge.subject: Alcohols
knowledge.object: metabolism of hydrocarbons by cytochrome p450 enzymes

details.name: Ketones
details.description: Compounds related to lipid peroxidation and are good predictors for ketosis.
details.findings: Acetone, a type of ketone, is a secondary product of lipid peroxidation and is formed under metabolic conditions associated with a high oxidation rate of fatty acids.

knowledge.subject: Acetone (a ketone)
knowledge.object: high oxidation rate of fatty acids

details.name: Esters
details.description: Compounds found in natural sources such as fats, oils, waxes, and fruit ethers.
details.findings: Esters can be found in large amounts in various natural sources including fats, oils, waxes, and fruit ethers.

knowledge.subject: Esters
knowledge.object: natural sources such as fats, oils, waxes, and fruit ethers

details.name: T-antigen
details.description: A cancer-associated glycan found in stool samples.
details.findings: Stools from more aggressive lesions may exhibit abnormal immature T-antigen signatures not seen in healthy tissues.

details.name: FIT (Fecal Immunochemical Test)
details.description: A non-invasive test used for colorectal cancer screening.
details.findings: The analysis of patients with negative FIT results is required to fully disclose the potential of T-antigen and T-expressing glycoproteoforms for non-invasive CRC screening.

knowledge.subject: FIT
knowledge.predicate: is required to fully disclose the potential of
knowledge.object: T-antigen and T-expressing glycoproteoforms for non-invasive CRC screening

details.name: T-expressing glycoproteoforms
details.description: Glycoproteins expressing the T-antigen found in stool samples.
details.findings: Future efforts should involve screening larger patient cohorts for both the T-antigen and T-expressing glycoproteoforms, ideally in multicenter settings.

knowledge.subject: T-expressing glycoproteoforms
knowledge.predicate: should be screened in larger patient cohorts

details.name: CRC Glycocode
details.description: The glycosylation patterns associated with colorectal cancer.
details.findings: This work showcases the unexplored potential of the CRC glycocode for non-invasive disease detection, providing a framework for addressing other potential relevant alterations in glycosylation in this context.

knowledge.subject: CRC Glycocode
knowledge.object: other potential relevant alterations in glycosylation

mistral-large/e_MJe.prompt_template:
[BEGIN ARTICLE]:<content></content>
[END ARTICLE]

[INSTRUCTIONS]
Generate list of biomarkers that are topic of the article and for each such biomarker extract name, description, type, findings explicitly mentioned in the article, and list of knowledge.
The list of knowledge that are from finding and that can be expressed in terms: "subject" which is the biomarker, "predicate" which is some verb optionally with some adverb and "object".
Return the response in strict JSON format with the following structure:

[
  { "name": "biomarker name","type":"biomarker type","description":"biomarker description","findings":"brief findings about biomarker in article as one sentence","notes":"additional notes important to biomarker or empty string", "knowledge":[{"subject":"repeated biomarker name","predicate":"some predicate from findings of biomarker","object":"object that relates via predicate to the biomarker" }],
  { "name": "biomarker2 name","type":"biomarker2 type","description":"biomarker2 description","findings":"brief findings about biomarker2 in article as one sentence","notes":"additional notes important to biomarker2 or empty string", "knowledge":[{"subject":"repeated biomarker2 name","predicate":"some predicate from findings of  biomarker2","object":"object that relates via predicate to the biomarker2" }] }
] 

Ensure there is no additional explanation, only return valid JSON.
